content: To demonstrate the viability of Ni–HAB as a practical 2e– ORR catalyst, we conducted the bulk electrosynthesis of H2O2 on a ∼1 cm2 Ni–HAB/CFP electrode (Figure S28) in O2-saturated 0.5 M NaPi buffer solution (pH = 6.64, 5 mL initial volume) with the potential of the electrode held constant in an H-cell. Aliquots of electrolytes (50 or 25 μL) were periodically taken out from the working chamber and added to portions of Ce­(SO4)2 that were measured spectroscopically by UV–vis spectroscopy (Figure S29) to determine the concentration of H2O2 (see the Supporting Information for details). The electrode was operated for 90 min at 0.6, 0.5, and then 0.4 V vs RHE in fresh solutions (a). In accordance with the RRDE measurements, as the electrolysis potential approached E redox, the total H2O2 concentration reached a peak of 662 ppm at 0.4 V vs RHE (b), which corresponds to a peak H2O2 yield of 86.2 μmol (c).
clean_text:
Bulk Electrochemical Synthesis of H2O2 in Neutral Media

To demonstrate the viability of Ni-HAB as a practical 2e- ORR catalyst, we conducted the bulk electrosynthesis of H2O2 on a ~1 cm2 Ni-HAB/CFP electrode (Figure S28) in O2-saturated 0.5 M NaPi buffer solution (pH = 6.64, 5 mL initial volume) with the potential of the electrode held constant in an H-cell. Aliquots of electrolytes (50 or 25 μL) were periodically taken out from the working chamber and added to portions of Ce(SO4)2 that were measured spectroscopically by UV-vis spectroscopy (Figure S29) to determine the concentration of H2O2 (see the Supporting Information for details). The electrode was operated for 90 min at 0.6, 0.5, and then 0.4 V vs RHE in fresh solutions (a). In accordance with the RRDE measurements, as the electrolysis potential approached E redox, the total H2O2 concentration reached a peak of 662 ppm at 0.4 V vs RHE (b), which corresponds to a peak H2O2 yield of 86.2 μmol (c).

meta.name: Bulk Electrochemical Synthesis of H2O2 in Neutral Media

other properties: total H2O2 concentration reached a peak of 662 ppm at 0.4 V vs RHE
